text: Hey are you feeling all right why don't
we Andy's directed by John Schlesinger
Billy Liar is the portrait of a young
day dreamer who likes so many of us
escapes from the humdrum reality of his
everyday life into a world of fantasy it
was a big day for us we had won the war
in Ambrosia democracy was back once more
in our beloved country
Billy or William Fisher as he's
officially known lived with his parents
in an industrial town in Yorkshire in
the early 1960s oh my god how dreary and
he's pissed again
he works at Shadrach and Duxbury a very
respectable Funeral furnishings firm
from which he's been embezzling a bit of
Teddy cash but Billy longs to move to
London and be a comedy writer he's a
pathological liar with a couple of good
friends and two fiancees who don't
realize that their time sharing a single
engagement ring prefers to spend his
time in ambrosia an imaginary country
where he's an aristocrat a celebrity a
soldier whatever he wants to be but
always a hero always the movie is full
of the Restless energy of England in
that era when the established social
order was beginning to crack open and
when the austerity of the immediate
post-war years was giving way to a new
consumer culture enter Julie Christie
she plays a character named Liz but
really she embodies the newly liberated
freewheeling spirit of the 1960s as a
script and I finished it it's gonna be
published next Christmas what impresses
Billy most about Liz is that she's free
even though she's living very much in
the real world you know what you wanted
me to do that night when we were walking
through the park and I said another
night yes it's another night tonight
isn't it
are you sure
the pathos and the comedy of Billy Liar
comes from the tension between two
different kinds of imagination the more
childish variety consists of making up
stuff that isn't true
it's ambrosia it's fun the other kind
which is no less creative involves
recognizing the world for what it is and
this can be painful
Billy fails to resolve this tension but
the movie as perhaps all great movies do
succeeds in having it both ways watching
Billy Liar we escaped to ambrosia and we
returned to reality
